messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 53 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Lower Bound for Succinct Range Minimum Query

Paper Abstract: Abstract Given an integer array A[1..n]A[1..n], the Range Minimum Query problem (RMQ) asks to preprocess A𝐴A into a data structure, supporting RMQ queries: given a,b∈[1,n]𝑎𝑏1𝑛a,b\in[1,n], return the index i∈[a,b]𝑖𝑎𝑏i\in[a,b] that minimizes A​[i]𝐴delimited-[]𝑖A[i], i.e., arg​mini∈[a,b]⁡A​[i]subscriptargmin𝑖𝑎𝑏𝐴delimited-[]𝑖\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{i\in[a,b]}A[i]. This problem has a classic solution using O​(n)𝑂𝑛O(n) space and O​(1)𝑂1O(1) query time by Gabow, Bentley, Tarjan [GBT84] and Harel, Tarjan [HT84]. The best known data structure by Fischer, Heun [FH11] and Navarro, Sadakane [NS14] uses 2​n+n/(log⁡nt)t+O~​(n3/4)2𝑛𝑛superscript𝑛𝑡𝑡~𝑂superscript𝑛342n+n/(\frac{\log n}{t})^{t}+\tilde{O}(n^{3/4}) bits and answers queries in O​(t)𝑂𝑡O(t) time, assuming the word-size is w=Θ​(log⁡n)𝑤Θ𝑛w=\Theta(\log n). In particular, it uses 2​n+n/poly​log⁡n2𝑛𝑛poly𝑛2n+n/\mathrm{poly}\log n bits of space when the query time is a constant. In this paper, we prove the first lower bound for this problem, showing that 2​n+n/poly​log⁡n2𝑛𝑛poly𝑛2n+n/\mathrm{poly}\log n space is necessary for constant query time. In general, we show that if the data structure has query time O​(t)𝑂𝑡O(t), then it must use at least 2​n+n/(log⁡n)O~​(t2)2𝑛𝑛superscript𝑛~𝑂superscript𝑡22n+n/(\log n)^{\tilde{O}(t^{2})} space, in the cell-probe model with word-size w=Θ​(log⁡n)𝑤Θ𝑛w=\Theta(\log n).

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 53 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 53"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Practical compressed suffix trees",
        "Efficient pattern matching with scaling",
        "Solutions to klee’s rectangle problems",
        "Lowest common ancestors in trees and directed acyclic graphs",
        "Random access to grammar-compressed strings and trees",
        "Recursive star-tree parallel data structure",
        "Sur les nombres de segner",
        "On the range maximum-sum segment query problem",
        "New unconditional hardness results for dynamic and online problems",
        "Improved algorithms for the range next value problem and applications",
        "Lempel–ziv factorization using less time & space",
        "An optimal randomized cell probe lower bound for approximate nearest neighbor searching",
        "On succinct representations of binary trees",
        "A new succinct representation of rmq-information and improvements in the enhanced suffix array",
        "Space-efficient preprocessing schemes for range minimum queries on static arrays",
        "Optimal string mining under frequency constraints",
        "Faster entropy-bounded compressed suffix trees",
        "Scaling and related techniques for geometry problems",
        "Compressed range minimum queries",
        "Towards tight lower bounds for range reporting on the RAM",
        "The cell probe complexity of succinct data structures",
        "Cell probe lower bounds for succinct data structures",
        "Finding dominators revisited: extended abstract",
        "Space-efficient framework for top-k string retrieval problems",
        "Fast algorithms for finding nearest common ancestors",
        "Succinct Static Data Structures",
        "Space-efficient static trees and graphs",
        "The cell probe complexity of dynamic range counting",
        "Higher cell probe lower bounds for evaluating polynomials",
        "Algorithms for finding the weight-constrained k longest paths in a tree and the length-constrained k maximum-sum segments of a sequence",
        "Time lower bounds for nonadaptive turnstile streaming algorithms",
        "Crossing the logarithmic barrier for dynamic boolean data structure lower bounds",
        "On data structures and asymmetric communication complexity",
        "Succinct representation of balanced parentheses and static trees",
        "Efficient algorithms for document retrieval problems",
        "Fully functional static and dynamic succinct trees",
        "Lower bound techniques for data structures",
        "Succincter",
        "Higher lower bounds for near-neighbor and further rich problems",
        "Time-space trade-offs for predecessor search",
        "A geometric approach to lower bounds for approximate near-neighbor search and partial match",
        "Lower bounds on near neighbor search via metric expansion",
        "Cell-probe lower bounds for succinct partial sums",
        "A proof of catalan’s convolution formula",
        "Efficient parallel triconnectivity in logarithmic time",
        "Compressed suffix trees with full functionality",
        "Succinct data structures for flexible text retrieval systems",
        "Dominance made simple",
        "Match chaining algorithms for cdna mapping",
        "Space-efficient algorithms for document retrieval",
        "Should tables be sorted?",
        "Simple average-case lower bounds for approximate near-neighbor from isoperimetric inequalities",
        "Optimal succinct rank data structure via approximate nonnegative tensor decomposition"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 53 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Lower Bound for Succinct Range Minimum Query, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
